{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3342117,"name":"Jackson M","username":"Indoraptor","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/indoraptor/{size}/221028_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-24T23:15:55.739Z","cooked":"

To keep things short and simple, our team is using the Fusion rack and pinion system on our robot this year, which is essentially a sprocket acting as the pinion going into holes in a 1x1 that acts as the rack. We had issues at our week 4 competition where we had to replace the 1x1s multiple times because they kept getting worn out to the point of turning the line of holes into more of a slot. We want to avoid doing this at our week 6 competition.
I’m wondering if anyone has any experience with this and if steel 1x1 box tube would hold up better in this scenario than aluminum 1x1 box tube.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2024-03-24T23:15:55.739Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":156,"reads":407,"readers_count":406,"score":891.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":459937,"topic_slug":"help-with-strength-aluminum-vs-steel-in-very-specific-scenario","display_username":"Jackson M","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62396,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/help-with-strength-aluminum-vs-steel-in-very-specific-scenario/459937/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3342134,"name":"","username":"AmbroseWiering","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ambrosewiering/{size}/195583_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-24T23:39:42.913Z","cooked":"

Is the slotting noticeably affecting the performance of the assembly? We have used the same concept on 1/8” wall aluminum tube for the last two years and have not had to replace the inner tube solely due to the slotting issue you are describing.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2024-03-24T23:39:42.913Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":386,"readers_count":385,"score":82.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":459937,"topic_slug":"help-with-strength-aluminum-vs-steel-in-very-specific-scenario","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":59604,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/help-with-strength-aluminum-vs-steel-in-very-specific-scenario/459937/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3342135,"name":"Jackson Crossley","username":"JacksonCrossley","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jacksoncrossley/{size}/184951_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-24T23:39:59.496Z","cooked":"

This is what the system looks like. Sorry I don’t have a photo of the actual 1x1, but after 20 minutes of use the holes look more blown out than the Panama Canal. At our week 4 we went through 4 different sets of 1x1’s.

image746×828 150 KB

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2024-03-24T23:39:59.496Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":365,"readers_count":364,"score":88.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":459937,"topic_slug":"help-with-strength-aluminum-vs-steel-in-very-specific-scenario","display_username":"Jackson Crossley","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/c/f/cfa46767de28dbabe07a7c9bbd1e3b9b34462fc8.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57165,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4065 Guy"},"post_url":"/t/help-with-strength-aluminum-vs-steel-in-very-specific-scenario/459937/3","custom_user_title":"4065 Guy","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3342140,"name":"Jackson Crossley","username":"JacksonCrossley","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jacksoncrossley/{size}/184951_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-24T23:49:47.523Z","cooked":"

I can’t speak on how exactly the slotting affected the performance of the lift, as I only ever really came in to fix the problem. I do know that the lift became extraordinary hard to move by hand once the slotting became too long.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2024-03-24T23:49:47.523Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":325,"readers_count":324,"score":80.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":459937,"topic_slug":"help-with-strength-aluminum-vs-steel-in-very-specific-scenario","display_username":"Jackson Crossley","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":59604,"username":"AmbroseWiering","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ambrosewiering/{size}/195583_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57165,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4065 Guy"},"post_url":"/t/help-with-strength-aluminum-vs-steel-in-very-specific-scenario/459937/4","custom_user_title":"4065 Guy","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3342153,"name":"osofdez","username":"osofdez","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/o/f14d63/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-25T00:08:02.230Z","cooked":"

Steel would definitively hold better than aluminum. If you have the weight go for it, if not you can add a steel reinforcement plate only to the face where the line of holes is, or I’ve seen some teams attach a chain for that purpose.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2024-03-25T00:08:02.230Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":302,"readers_count":301,"score":160.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":459937,"topic_slug":"help-with-strength-aluminum-vs-steel-in-very-specific-scenario","display_username":"osofdez","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":29869,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/help-with-strength-aluminum-vs-steel-in-very-specific-scenario/459937/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3342206,"name":"Jackson M","username":"Indoraptor","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/indoraptor/{size}/221028_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-25T01:12:44.272Z","cooked":"

we’re about 17 pounds under weight so this is probably the route we’ll go. thanks for the advice.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2024-03-25T01:12:44.272Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":268,"readers_count":267,"score":53.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":459937,"topic_slug":"help-with-strength-aluminum-vs-steel-in-very-specific-scenario","display_username":"Jackson M","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":29869,"username":"osofdez","name":"osofdez","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/o/f14d63/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62396,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/help-with-strength-aluminum-vs-steel-in-very-specific-scenario/459937/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3342635,"name":"Kara Bakowski","username":"Karibou","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/karibou/{size}/193241_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-25T13:37:30.226Z","cooked":"

Do you know what grades of aluminum the sprocket and aluminum tubing are made of?

Do you have a picture of the sprocket?

What size holes are those? What size sprocket are you using?

You should also check the alignment of everything in the system, on every axis - that could be causing the sprocket to be “pushed” further into the holes than intended.

osofdez:

Steel would definitively hold better than aluminum. If you have the weight go for it, if not you can add a steel reinforcement plate only to the face where the line of holes is, or I’ve seen some teams attach a chain for that purpose.

Not necessarily! Depends on the specific grades of steel and aluminum.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2024-03-25T13:37:30.226Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":228,"readers_count":227,"score":70.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":459937,"topic_slug":"help-with-strength-aluminum-vs-steel-in-very-specific-scenario","display_username":"Kara Bakowski","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9018,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"she/her/hers"},"post_url":"/t/help-with-strength-aluminum-vs-steel-in-very-specific-scenario/459937/7","custom_user_title":"she/her/hers","reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3342657,"name":"ToddF","username":"ToddF","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/toddf/{size}/5508_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-25T14:05:46.096Z","cooked":"
Karibou:

Not necessarily! Depends on the specific grades of steel and aluminum.

Exactly. AL 7075-T6 is great stuff and is stronger than most mild steels and non-hardened stainless.

Aluminum 7075-T6: Yield 73ksi, Ultimate 83ksi
mild steel 1018: Yield 54ksi, Ultimate 64ksi
steel 1040: Yield 60ksi, Ultimate 90ksi

Once you get into high carbon heat treated steels, the strength gets much better than AL 7075-T6, but they are a real bear to machine for a typical FRC team.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2024-03-25T14:06:17.385Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":198,"readers_count":197,"score":64.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":459937,"topic_slug":"help-with-strength-aluminum-vs-steel-in-very-specific-scenario","display_username":"ToddF","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16376,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/help-with-strength-aluminum-vs-steel-in-very-specific-scenario/459937/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3342738,"name":"Devin Castellucci","username":"RoboChair","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/robochair/{size}/161076_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-25T15:13:47.109Z","cooked":"

7075 is magic

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2024-03-25T15:13:47.109Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":172,"readers_count":171,"score":49.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":459937,"topic_slug":"help-with-strength-aluminum-vs-steel-in-very-specific-scenario","display_username":"Devin Castellucci","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":16376,"username":"ToddF","name":"ToddF","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/toddf/{size}/5508_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7460,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1678 Fab Mentor and 5458 Tech Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/help-with-strength-aluminum-vs-steel-in-very-specific-scenario/459937/9","custom_user_title":"1678 Fab Mentor and 5458 Tech Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3343100,"name":"osofdez","username":"osofdez","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/o/f14d63/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-25T19:21:27.034Z","cooked":"

I can assure you the 1x1 they are using is not 7075, and almost any comercially available steel 1x1 will be stronger than what they are using right now, given the same thickness. So from a practical point of view a steel 1x1 would be stronger than an aluminum one.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2024-03-25T19:21:27.034Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":135,"readers_count":134,"score":32.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":459937,"topic_slug":"help-with-strength-aluminum-vs-steel-in-very-specific-scenario","display_username":"osofdez","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":16376,"username":"ToddF","name":"ToddF","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/toddf/{size}/5508_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":29869,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/help-with-strength-aluminum-vs-steel-in-very-specific-scenario/459937/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3343266,"name":"Kara Bakowski","username":"Karibou","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/karibou/{size}/193241_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-25T21:10:14.178Z","cooked":"

I don’t think that’s a good assumption. 1005 steel (which is what McMaster offers as its “low carbon steel rectangular tube”) has a yield strength ~32ksi, and 6061-T6 aluminum has a yield strength ~35ksi.

The material of the tube isn’t the only variable here; if the sprocket is 7075-T6, it’s going to keep doing the same thing (maybe just a bit slower) even if the tube is changed to a steel with a yield strength in the 45-55ksi range, which is going to be what you get for most easily-available steel tubing.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2024-03-25T21:10:14.382Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":116,"readers_count":115,"score":63.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":459937,"topic_slug":"help-with-strength-aluminum-vs-steel-in-very-specific-scenario","display_username":"Kara Bakowski","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":29869,"username":"osofdez","name":"osofdez","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/o/f14d63/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9018,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":"Automatically removed quote of whole previous post.","can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"she/her/hers"},"post_url":"/t/help-with-strength-aluminum-vs-steel-in-very-specific-scenario/459937/11","custom_user_title":"she/her/hers","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3343293,"name":"Camren","username":"Camren","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/camren/{size}/226239_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-25T21:44:57.780Z","cooked":"
Karibou:

The material of the tube isn’t the only variable here

@Indoraptor

  • What sprocket are you using?
  • What is your hole size?
  • How much engagement is there between the sprocket and the hole?
  • How much force is on the arm?

Theoretically you could overbuild your system by using a 7075 tube or a hardened steel reinforcing plate riveted to the 1x1 tube, but if you want the correct answer then you should do the math to determine what the correct material is.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2024-03-25T21:45:40.901Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":97,"readers_count":96,"score":29.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":459937,"topic_slug":"help-with-strength-aluminum-vs-steel-in-very-specific-scenario","display_username":"Camren","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16209,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/help-with-strength-aluminum-vs-steel-in-very-specific-scenario/459937/12","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3343317,"name":"","username":"flametek","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/flametek/{size}/235833_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-25T22:06:50.858Z","cooked":"

We use a VexPro #35 aluminum 15t to power the aluminum 1x1. The sprocket interfaces with the 1x1 through a #18 hole (0.1695in). There is about 0.2" of tooth engagement if I had to guess and about 1 and a half teeth engagement. It sees a load of a 17lb intake vertically and a fair bit of horizontal load while driving.

We went out to Home Depot tonight and picked up some A36 hot rolled steel 1x1 box tube to replace the aluminum, and ordered steel sprockets to replace the aluminum ones as well.

edit: tomorrow I will grab pictures of the slotting on the aluminum tubes

flametek:

VexPro #35 aluminum 15t

You want the sprocket to be less hard than the “pinion”, Then you can wear in the sprocket to mate better with the “pinion”

The problem with this setup is the contact surface has such a small surface area that the force applied will likely be far greater than the yield strength regardless of the materials used.

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2024-03-25T22:39:25.263Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":13,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":72,"readers_count":71,"score":34.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":459937,"topic_slug":"help-with-strength-aluminum-vs-steel-in-very-specific-scenario","display_username":"Camren","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16209,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/help-with-strength-aluminum-vs-steel-in-very-specific-scenario/459937/14","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3343387,"name":"Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)","username":"ngreen","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ngreen/{size}/264478_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-25T23:12:09.993Z","cooked":"

We did have slotting happening on our PwF style extender last year, but only at the end of it, most likely when the limits were mildly exceeded. It never reached the point that we couldn’t move it, but we did file the slot a little so the tooth couldn’t stick into the groove.

We had the 0.375" spaced holes in 6061 1x1x1/8" tubing and used the 10T AM #35 sprocket (https://www.andymark.com/products/35-series-symmetrical-hub-sprockets)
